title: Solutions / Knowledge Base: The Basics
text: Articles inherit the permissions of their top-level folder. We have set the INTERNAL folders to being viewed by support agents only, and the customer folders are restricted to be searched/viewed on the customer portal only if the company that the logged in person is associated with has the relevant product for each section (i.e. if you are a DdD customer, you will only see DdD articles, not the MStore, Imagine etc). It is possible for customers to be associated with multiple products When you create or edit an article, you are given the option (top right) to Save or Publish. If you only Save, your article will be a draft and no one will see it Note that there is an option to send for review on the Publish button. We are not enforcing review before publishing (so be careful when creating articles for customers!), but you still have the option to use this if you would like a colleague to review. Images/screenshots are good to help people understand and keep them engaged. If the article is long, then use the TOC button on the toolbar to insert a Table of Contents. The TOC does not update as you add more sections, so add the TOC last, and if you add more sections when the TOC is already there, you will need to highlight the TOC and click the TOC button again (i..e delete it and re-add it again) Note that the TOC does not update as you add more sections, so add the TOC last, and if you add more sections when the TOC is already there, you will need to delete it and re-add it again You can add notes in a box by clicking the add button on an empty line, and choosing which type/colour note you want to add. This helps to highlight key things, especially if the article is long

title: Language to use in the KB and translations
text: All internal articles should be in English Customer articles should be in English unless it's a product where only one language is ever used by customers (e.g. Cowis which is only in German) When customers submit a ticket or search the KB, it will only search articles in the language which they have selected. For this reason, there is an article which tells customers which and redirects them to be using the portal in English if they wish. Customers can use the portal in their own selected language because ticket fields and email notifications etc have been translated You can add translations of the English into any other language by clicking the Translate button against the relevant language (you don't need to be editing the English article for this option to be available). Translations are not mandatory. If you do enter a translation, you will be asked to enter translations for the folder structure the article is in unless someone has already done this In any folder (not article) you can change the language to see all articles in that language It is not possible to create articles inn only one language unless it's English. In other words, if you want to create articles just in German, for example, you will have to create the English version first.

    • Customers can use the portal in their own selected language because ticket fields and email notifications etc have been translated
  • You can add translations of the English into any other language by clicking the Translate button against the relevant language (you don't need to be editing the English article for this option to be available). 
    • Translations are not mandatory. If you do enter a translation, you will be asked to enter translations for the folder structure the article is in unless someone has already done this


  • In any folder (not article) you can change the language to see all articles in that language
  • It is not possible to create articles inn only one language unless it's English. In other words, if you want to create articles just in German, for example, you will have to create the English version first.

text: Folders should be used for sub-divisions of logically similar information. Note that articles in same folder will be suggested as possible other articles to read to customers on portal. Note: BE CAREFUL WITH PERMISSIONS when creating folders

title: BE CAREFUL WITH PERMISSIONS when creating folders
text: Access permissions are set on the top level folders within each category (example category being "Imagine Documentation"). Below are the three top-level folders within the "INTERNAL Support Articles" category. The top level folder affects what customers see. Therefore do not create any top level folders in an Internal category (but if you agree with support management that you will add one, then set the permissions to Agents only Sub-folders inherit the permissions of the top level folder automatically. For folders in customer-facing categories (e.g. "Imagine documentation" or "MStore"), the folder permissions should be set so that only companies tagged with having the relevant product can see it Note that the product(s) selection which affects this is held on the Company record (not Contracts)

title: How to link articles
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Searching for an Article Copy/Paste the Link Beware!! It's often useful to put in a link to another article (to save repeating content). Searching for an Article To do this, simply click on the "Insert Link" icon or click Ctrl+K and select the Solution Article tab (from where you can search for your article). Once your article has come up in the search results, you can either: Click the "Add" button which comes up when you hover over the article OR Click on the article to open up a window which shows you the contents, then click the Add button, then click the arrow top left of that window You'll then be back at the screen below where you can click on the Insert button to finally insert your link Here's the example! ** READ ME ** Copy/Paste the Link On any article which you are viewing or editing, you can click on the Copy Link icon and paste that into another article. Beware!! If you use the search dialogue box or the link button described in the two sections above,, the link will take you to the portal view of the article. This is because it's designed with linking public/customer articles in mind which is great... The only way to get around this if you are linking internal articles and dont' want to go to the portal view is to copy the address from the browser address bar, but it will then paste with the generic display name of Helpdesk : K3 Support (freshdesk.com) which isn't very helpful (you can of course change this by clicking the link when editing an article and change the display text.

description:
TABLE OF CONTENTS

  • Searching for an Article
  • Copy/Paste the Link
  • Beware!!

It's often useful to put in a link to another article (to save repeating content).


Searching for an Article

To do this, simply click on the "Insert Link" icon or click Ctrl+K and select the Solution Article tab (from where you can search for your article).




Once your article has come up in the search results, you can either:

  1. Click the "Add" button which comes up when you hover over the article

    OR
  2. Click on the article to open up a window which shows you the contents, then click the Add button, then click the arrow top left of that window

    You'll then be back at the screen below where you can click on the Insert button to finally insert your link


Here's the example! ** READ ME **


Copy/Paste the Link

On any article which you are viewing or editing, you can click on the Copy Link icon and paste that into another article.


Beware!!

If you use the search dialogue box or the link button described in the two sections  above,, the link will take you to the portal view of the article. This is because it's designed with linking public/customer articles in mind which is great...

The only way to get around this if you are linking internal articles and dont' want to go to the portal view is to copy the address from the browser address bar, but it will then paste with the generic display name of Helpdesk : K3 Support (freshdesk.com)  which isn't very helpful (you can of course change this by clicking the link when editing an article and change the display text.

text: If you are working on a ticket and are only able to "insert content" and not "link to article", as shown below. Then you need to check the information of the company. Go to the company page in Freshdesk and check the information in the data field. If it looks like this Then you need to contact your manager as the companies information is not updated. title: DON'T COPY/PASTE FROM ONENOTE
text: If you copy/paste from OneNote, you will only end up pasting an image of what was in OneNote. This means that text won't be indexed/searchable, so it's best avoided. This is a known issue with OneNote. You can use a keyboard shortcut to copy/paste as plain text, but this obviously won't include any images of formatting. The best way of retaining the original formatting is to export from OneNote (or copy/paste) to Word, then copy from Word into Freshdesk

title: Unpublish or Archive an Article
text: If you want to Unpublish an article (so the article still exists, but is not visible on the customer portal), then just Edit the article, and select the Unpublish option as shown in the example below. If the article is in multiple languages, you will need to unpublish each language version It's not possible to hide the article from internal users/agents, so if you want to keep the article, but move it to a place where it won't be found by anyone internal browsing articles, you can move it to the Archive folder (and add whatever folder structure you want). You might also want to add a tag "Archive" to the article which can be done by Editing the article, then clicking the Edit article properties as seen below
